immunotherapy_overview.formula: Immunotherapy treats diseases by modulating the body's immune response, either activating or suppressing it
immunotherapy_overview.correct: Activation immunotherapies enhance immune responses; suppression immunotherapies reduce harmful immune activity

wrong.fix: Immunotherapy modulates (enhances or suppresses) the existing immune system
wrong.action: Immunotherapy = modulate existing immunity, not replace it

wrong.answer: All immunotherapies activate the immune system
wrong.fix: Some immunotherapies activate (for cancer); others suppress (for autoimmunity)
wrong.action: Activation = cancer; Suppression = autoimmune diseases

wrong.answer: Immunotherapy is the same as vaccination
wrong.fix: Vaccines prevent disease; immunotherapy treats existing disease
wrong.action: Vaccines = prevention; Immunotherapy = treatment

persistent.action: Immunotherapy: activation (cancer) or suppression (autoimmune), modulates immune response

monoclonal_antibodies.formula: Monoclonal antibodies are identical antibodies produced from a single B cell clone targeting specific epitopes
monoclonal_antibodies.correct: Hybridoma technology fuses plasma cells with immortal tumour cells to produce unlimited identical antibodies

wrong.answer: Monoclonal antibodies are produced by mixing different antibodies
wrong.fix: Monoclonal = from one clone (identical); Polyclonal = from multiple clones (mixed)
wrong.action: Mono = one; Poly = many; Clonal = from same cell

wrong.answer: Monoclonal antibodies are made directly in patients
wrong.fix: Monoclonal antibodies are produced in laboratories using hybridoma cells
wrong.action: Lab production: antigen → mouse → plasma cells + tumour cells → hybridoma

wrong.fix: Each monoclonal antibody recognises only one specific epitope
wrong.action: Monoclonal = one epitope; Polyclonal = multiple epitopes

persistent.gap: Confusion about monoclonal antibody production and specificity
persistent.action: Monoclonal: one clone → one epitope → identical antibodies → specific targeting

hybridoma_technology.formula: Hybridoma cells are created by fusing antigen-specific plasma cells with immortal myeloma cells
hybridoma_technology.correct: The hybridoma combines antibody production capability with unlimited cell division

wrong.fix: Hybridomas are artificially created fusion cells, not natural
wrong.action: Hybridoma = hybrid (fusion) + oma (tumour-like) = artificial

wrong.answer: Any cell can be used to make hybridomas
wrong.fix: Hybridomas require plasma cells (for antibody production) and myeloma cells (for immortality)
wrong.action: Plasma cell (antibody) + Myeloma (immortal) = Hybridoma

wrong.answer: Hybridomas can only make one batch of antibodies
wrong.fix: Hybridomas are immortal and can produce unlimited quantities of antibodies
wrong.action: Immortal hybridoma = endless antibody production

persistent.action: Process: immunise mouse → harvest plasma cells → fuse with myeloma → select hybridoma

cancer_treatment.formula: Monoclonal antibodies treat cancer by targeting tumour antigens, blocking checkpoints, or delivering drugs
cancer_treatment.correct: Cancer cells express neoantigens that can be targeted by specifically designed monoclonal antibodies

wrong.answer: Cancer cells are always attacked by the immune system
wrong.fix: Cancer cells often evade immunity; immunotherapy helps the immune system recognise them
wrong.action: Cancer evades immunity; immunotherapy overcomes evasion

wrong.answer: Monoclonal antibodies directly kill all cancer cells
wrong.fix: Antibodies work through various mechanisms: opsonisation, checkpoint blocking, drug delivery
wrong.action: Mechanisms: marking for destruction, blocking inhibition, targeting drugs

wrong.fix: Immunotherapy effectiveness varies; not all patients or cancers respond
wrong.action: Response varies by cancer type, patient factors, and tumour characteristics

persistent.gap: Incomplete understanding of cancer immunotherapy mechanisms
persistent.action: Mechanisms: opsonisation, checkpoint inhibition, antibody-drug conjugates

checkpoint_inhibitors.formula: Checkpoint inhibitors block regulatory proteins that normally suppress T cell activity against cancer
checkpoint_inhibitors.correct: Blocking checkpoints like PD-1 or CTLA-4 releases the brakes on T cell anti-tumour responses

wrong.fix: Checkpoint inhibitors RELEASE suppression, allowing stronger immune responses
wrong.action: Inhibit the inhibitor = activate immunity

wrong.fix: Checkpoints are normal regulatory proteins; cancers exploit them to avoid immunity
wrong.action: Checkpoints = normal regulation; Cancer = exploits for evasion

wrong.answer: Checkpoint inhibitors have no side effects
wrong.fix: Releasing immune suppression can cause autoimmune-like side effects
wrong.action: More immunity = risk of attacking healthy tissue

persistent.action: Checkpoints = brakes on immunity; Inhibitors = release brakes → stronger anti-cancer response

autoimmune_diseases.formula: Autoimmune diseases occur when the immune system attacks self-tissues due to loss of tolerance
autoimmune_diseases.correct: Antigenic mimicry by pathogens can trigger cross-reactive immune responses against host tissues

wrong.fix: Autoimmune diseases involve immune attack on self; infections involve pathogens
wrong.action: Autoimmune = self-attack; Infection = pathogen attack

wrong.fix: Autoimmunity involves genetic predisposition plus environmental triggers
wrong.action: Causes: genetics + environment (infection, stress, etc.)

wrong.fix: Most autoimmune diseases are managed, not cured; treatment reduces symptoms
wrong.action: Current treatment = management; Cure = not yet available for most

persistent.action: Autoimmunity: loss of self-tolerance → immune attack on own tissues

autoimmune_treatment.formula: Monoclonal antibodies treat autoimmune diseases by targeting inflammatory mediators or immune cells
autoimmune_treatment.correct: Anti-TNF antibodies reduce inflammation in rheumatoid arthritis; anti-CD20 depletes B cells in some diseases

wrong.fix: Autoimmune treatment SUPPRESSES harmful immune responses; cancer treatment activates them
wrong.action: Autoimmune = suppress; Cancer = activate

wrong.answer: One antibody treats all autoimmune diseases
wrong.fix: Different autoimmune diseases require different targeted treatments
wrong.action: Specific targets for specific diseases

wrong.fix: Suppressing immunity increases infection risk and requires monitoring
wrong.action: Less immunity = more infection risk

persistent.action: Treatment targets: TNF (inflammation), B cells (CD20), T cells, cytokines

tnf_inhibitors.formula: Anti-TNF antibodies block tumour necrosis factor, reducing inflammation in conditions like rheumatoid arthritis
tnf_inhibitors.correct: TNF is a pro-inflammatory cytokine; blocking it reduces joint damage and symptoms

wrong.fix: TNF inhibitors manage symptoms and slow progression but don't cure the disease
wrong.action: Treatment = management; Not = cure

wrong.fix: TNF has important roles in normal immunity; only excess TNF causes problems
wrong.action: Normal TNF = useful; Excess TNF = harmful inflammation

wrong.answer: TNF inhibitors are safe for everyone
wrong.fix: TNF inhibitors increase infection risk and are not suitable for patients with active infections
wrong.action: Contraindications: active infections, certain cancers, heart failure

persistent.gap: Incomplete understanding of TNF and its inhibition
persistent.action: TNF = inflammatory cytokine; Anti-TNF = reduces inflammation but increases infection risk
